DOCNAME: CASE OF RUSSIAN CONSERVATIVE PARTY OF ENTREPRENEURS v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of P3-1 in respect of the applicant party and the second applicant;No Violation of P3-1 in respect of the third applicant;Violation of Art. 13 in respect of the applicant party and the second applicant;No violation of Art. 13 in respect of the third applicant;Violation of P1-1 in respect of the applicant party;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Pecuniary damage - financial award (applicant party);Costs and expenses award - domestic and Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant party , ORG ( Российская консервативная партия предпринимателей ) , is a nationwide political party established under the laws of GPE .
The second applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He stood as CARDINAL of the applicant party 's candidates for the DATE elections to ORG .
The third applicant , PERSON PERSON , was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was a supporter of the applicant party .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant party nominated CARDINAL candidates for the elections to ORG of GPE , the lower chamber of the NORP bicameral parliament .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE ( Центральная избирательная комиссия РФ – “ the ORG ” ) confirmed receipt of the applicant party 's list of candidates . The applicant party paid the election deposit .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused to register the applicant party 's list , with reference to sections DATE ) , CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( d ) , CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . The ORG established that CARDINAL candidates had submitted substantially inaccurate information about their income and property and struck them off the list . CARDINAL of them was the number CARDINAL candidate on the list . On that ground the ORG decided :

“ CARDINAL . To refuse the registration of the federal list of candidates to ORG of GPE nominated by [ the applicant party ] because of the withdrawal [ выбытие ] of the candidate listed as number CARDINAL in the nationwide section of the accepted federal list of candidates . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant party appealed to a court against the ORG 's refusal to register it .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG of GPE , acting as a first - instance court , upheld the ORG 's decision to remove from the list the candidates who had made false representations , but declared unlawful the ORG 's refusal to register the list in its entirety . The court interpreted the term “ withdrawal ” in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW as meaning only a candidate 's voluntary withdrawal of his or her own free will . The court therefore held that the provision should not apply to a situation where one of the top CARDINAL candidates had been struck off the list by the ORG .
CARDINAL . The ORG appealed against that judgment . The applicant party submitted its observations on the ORG 's grounds of appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG of GPE upheld the judgment of DATE . The court thoroughly analysed the wording of LAW and agreed that the word “ withdrawal ” in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW should only refer to situations where the candidate 's name had been taken off the list of the candidate 's own free will or at the request of the candidate 's electoral union .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG allowed the registration of the applicant party 's list of candidates .

CARDINAL . On DATE a deputy Prosecutor General of GPE lodged an application for supervisory review with the Presidium of ORG of GPE . The prosecutor argued that “ withdrawal ” was a generic term which applied to any situation where a candidate was struck off the list , be it the expression of will of the candidate himself , of his electoral union , or of the ORG . Hence a candidate 's exclusion as a result of the ORG 's decision should count as “ withdrawal ” and thus render section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW applicable .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of ORG of GPE granted the application for supervisory review and quashed the judgment of DATE . The court followed the line of reasoning suggested by the deputy ORG . The court emphasised that the exclusion of a candidate from the list as a result of the ORG 's decision was only a specific instance of “ withdrawal ” and that the ORG 's refusal to register the list had therefore been lawful .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG annulled its earlier decisions , refused the registration of the applicant party 's list and ordered the applicant party 's name to be removed from the ballot papers . The applicant party appealed against the ORG 's decision to ORG of GPE . On DATE ORG of GPE dismissed the applicant party 's complaint . The court found that pursuant to the judgment of the ORG of ORG of GPE , the ORG had no discretion in the matter and it was obliged as a matter of law to refuse the registration of the applicant party 's list .
CARDINAL . On DATE the elections to ORG took place . The applicant party was not listed in the voting papers .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE , acting on an application by a group of NORP MPs , declared unconstitutional the part of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW which provided for the refusal or cancellation of a party 's registration in the event of the withdrawal of CARDINAL of the top CARDINAL candidates on the list .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court stressed that the right to stand for election was an individual rather than a collective right . However , the contested provision made the exercise of that right conditional on the consistent presence of the top CARDINAL candidates on the list , which amounted to a restriction on the other candidates ' right to stand for election and on the citizens ' right to vote for them . It violated the principle of equality between the candidates because it only applied in the event of withdrawal of CARDINAL of the top CARDINAL candidates but not of those in lower positions on the list . Such a restriction could not be justified by the special role played by the top CARDINAL candidates , who were usually political heavyweights , in the electoral campaign and it did not serve any legitimate aim listed in the LAW .

CARDINAL . NORP Moreover , withdrawal of CARDINAL of the top CARDINAL candidates had a disproportionately crippling effect on the electoral union or bloc , which forfeited the right to stand for election through no fault of its own . On the other hand , it made it difficult for the top CARDINAL candidates to leave an electoral union whose platform had changed to the point of being inconsistent with their own views . It also encroached on the active voting rights of the electorate , depriving them of an opportunity to vote for the candidates and impairing the formation of a representative spectrum of members of ORG .

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG noted that the refusal or cancellation of registration was essentially a sanction imposed on an electoral union or bloc . Sanctions could only be inflicted for violations of the electoral laws and should be proportionate to the violation . However , the contested provision made it possible to sanction electoral unions , blocs and other candidates who had not committed any violation , and this was incompatible with the general principles of justice and rule of law .

CARDINAL . ORG also ruled that the finding that section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) was unconstitutional was of no consequence for the State Duma elections of DATE and could not be relied upon to seek a review of their results .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE disallowed the applicant party 's application for review of the compatibility of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) with LAW , because the subject - matter of the application was essentially the same as the matter adjudicated on DATE .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant party lodged an application with the ORG of ORG of GPE to review the judgment of DATE in the light of a new circumstance , namely the ruling of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of ORG refused the applicant party 's application . The court ruled that the ruling of ORG was not a new circumstance under domestic law and that , in any event , the applicant party had failed to comply with the procedural time - limit of DATE for lodging its application for a review .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant party applied to the ORG to have its election deposit paid back .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE , the ORG informed the applicant party that the election deposit had been credited to the federal budget and could not be repaid . The ORG maintained that the decision of ORG did not apply to the DATE elections and that there was consequently no ground for returning the election deposit .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant party brought a civil action against the ORG for the return of the election deposit .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG of GPE dismissed the applicant party 's action . The court based its decision on a provision of LAW to the effect that the election deposit could not be repaid if the party 's list had not been registered in accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW . The court held that the applicant party 's request for the return of the deposit on the basis of ORG ruling was in fact a disguised request for a review of the election results , which had been expressly prohibited by ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld on appeal the judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . The relevant parts of LAW ( DATE ) adopted by ORG on DATE , read as follows :

CARDINAL . The Code of Good Practice was adopted by ORG ) at its CARDINALst ( Guidelines ) and CARDINALnd ( Report ) sessions on DATE and DATE ( Opinion no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG ( DATE ) CARDINAL rev . ) .
CARDINAL . Guidelines on Elections provide as follows :
“ The CARDINAL principles underlying LOC 's electoral heritage are universal , equal , free , secret and direct suffrage . Furthermore , elections must be held at regular intervals .
CARDINAL . Freedom of voters to form an opinion
a. State authorities must observe their duty of neutrality . In particular , this concerns :
i. media ;
ii . billposting ;
iii . the right to demonstrate ;
iv . funding of parties and candidates .
b. The public authorities have a number of positive obligations ; inter alia , they must :
i. submit the candidatures received to the electorate ;
ii . enable voters to know the lists and candidates standing for election , for example through appropriate posting .
iii . The above information must also be available in the languages of the national minorities .
c. Sanctions must be imposed in the case of breaches of duty of neutrality and voters ' freedom to form an opinion .
CARDINAL . Freedom of voters to express their wishes and action to combat electoral fraud
i. voting procedures must be simple ;
ii . voters should always have the possibility of voting in a polling station ...
vii . CARDINAL criteria should be used to assess the accuracy of the outcome of the ballot : the number of votes cast and the number of voting slips placed in the ballot box ...
x. polling stations must include representatives of a number of parties , and the presence of observers appointed by the candidates must be permitted during voting and counting ...
xiii . counting must be transparent . Observers , candidates ' representatives and the media must be allowed to be present . These persons must also have access to the records ;
xv . the state must punish any kind of electoral fraud . ”
CARDINAL . Explanatory Report reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . Free suffrage

CARDINAL . Free suffrage comprises CARDINAL different aspects : free formation of the elector 's opinion , and free expression of this opinion , i.e. freedom of voting procedure and accurate assessment of the result .
CARDINAL Freedom of voters to form an opinion

a. Freedom of voters to form an opinion partly overlaps with equality of opportunity . It requires the state DATE and public authorities generally DATE to honour their duty of even - handedness , particularly where the use of the mass media , billposting , the right to demonstrate on public thoroughfares and the funding of parties and candidates are concerned .

b. Public authorities also have certain positive obligations . They must submit lawfully presented candidatures to the citizens ' votes . The presentation of specific candidatures may be prohibited only in exceptional circumstances , where necessitated by a greater public interest . Public authorities must also give the electorate access to lists and candidates standing for election by means , for instance , of appropriate billposting ...
CARDINAL . Freedom of voters to express their wishes and combating electoral fraud

CARDINAL . Freedom of voters to express their wishes primarily requires strict observance of the voting procedure . In practice , electors should be able to cast their votes for registered lists or candidates , which means that they must be supplied with ballot papers bearing their names and that they must be able to deposit the ballot papers in a ballot box . ... Electors must be protected from threats or constraints liable to prevent them from casting their votes or from casting them as they wish , whether such threats come from the authorities or from individuals ; the state is obliged to prevent and penalise such practices . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant part of the summary of the findings of ORG on the parliamentary elections in GPE ( DATE ) , prepared by ORG ) , reads as follows :

“ In general , and in spite of episodic challenges that could have undermined the general integrity of the process as a whole , the State PERSON elections marked significant progress in consolidating representative democracy in GPE . They reflected a political environment in which voters had a broad spectrum of political forces from which to choose .

A solid turnout demonstrated a respectable level of public confidence in the process , and the final result showed a significant increase in the representative share of overall voter support actually included in LOC .

The electoral laws governing the process had improved significantly with each successive election and were found to be consistent with commonly recognized democratic principles , including those formulated in ORG of DATE . This legal framework provided a sound basis for the conduct of orderly , pluralistic and accountable elections .

The law provides the framework for parties and blocs to enter the political arena on an equal basis and provides a foundation for maintaining a level playing field for political participants . In particular , the law provided a basis for equal access to free media time for all participants , and instituted rigid parameters for enforcing accountability measures and controlling the use of campaign funds .

The political campaigns were competitive and pluralistic with CARDINAL parties and blocs ultimately competing on the federal list and CARDINAL to CARDINAL candidates appearing on ballots for the single - mandate constituency races ... ”
